definitions: disagree with and attempt to prevent something from happening by argument or action
compete against someone in a contest, election, or conflict
examples: Many citizens oppose the construction of the new highway
The senator will oppose any cuts to education funding
The two teams will oppose each other in tomorrow's championship
She opposed the incumbent mayor in last year's election

definitions: politely refuse an invitation, request, or offer without accepting it
become smaller, fewer, or less in size, amount, intensity, or quality
examples: She had to decline the dinner invitation due to illness
He declined to comment on the ongoing investigation
Sales have declined steadily over the past three months
His health began to decline after the accident

definitions: cause something to come toward something else by exerting a force or influence
cause someone to have a liking for or interest in something
examples: Magnets attract iron filings and other metal objects
The light attracts moths and other insects at night
The new museum attracts thousands of visitors each month
Her confident personality attracts people to her

definitions: cause to divide or move apart into different sections, groups, or places
stop living together as a couple while remaining legally married
examples: Use a comma to separate items in a list
The teacher separated the fighting students immediately
The couple decided to separate after ten years
They separated but never officially divorced

definitions: take air into the lungs and then expel it as a regular physiological process
take a pause or rest to recover composure or strength
examples: It's hard to breathe at high altitudes
The doctor asked her to breathe deeply
Let the wine breathe before serving it
Give me a moment to breathe after that workout

definitions: stop or discontinue an action, habit, or activity permanently
leave a job, school, or position voluntarily
examples: He finally quit smoking after twenty years
She quit complaining and started finding solutions
I decided to quit my job and start a business
Three employees quit without giving notice

definitions: pull someone or something along forcefully, roughly, or with difficulty
continue for longer than necessary in a boring or tedious way
examples: She had to drag the heavy suitcase up the stairs
Don't drag your feet when you walk
The meeting seemed to drag on for hours
The court case has been dragging for years

definitions: put something in a prominent place so that it may readily be seen
show a particular behavior, emotion, or quality openly
examples: The store displays its newest products in the window
Museums display artifacts from ancient civilizations
He displayed great courage during the emergency
She displayed no emotion during the trial

definitions: accomplish an aim or purpose after effort, planning, or perseverance
take over a position, office, or title from someone else
examples: She worked hard to succeed in her career
The business succeeded beyond their wildest dreams
The vice president will succeed the retiring CEO
Prince Charles succeeded Queen Elizabeth as monarch

definitions: separate or break up something into parts, groups, or sections
cause people to disagree or form opposing groups
examples: Divide the cake into eight equal pieces
The teacher divided the class into small groups
The controversial issue divided the community
Politics shouldn't divide families and friends

definitions: go out with someone in whom one has a romantic interest
establish or ascertain the age or time of origin of something
examples: They started dating in college
She's dating someone from her office
Scientists can date fossils using carbon testing
This painting dates to the Renaissance period

definitions: have or express a different opinion from someone else about something
examples: The committee members disagree about the budget allocation
I respectfully disagree with your analysis of the situation

definitions: consider or think of someone or something in a specified way
look steadily and intently at someone or something
examples: She regards him as her mentor and friend
Many regard this as the best restaurant in town
He regarded her with suspicion
She regarded the painting thoughtfully

definitions: cover or enclose something in paper, cloth, or other material
finish filming, recording, or other work
examples: Please wrap this gift in colorful paper
She wrapped the baby in a warm blanket
Let's wrap up this meeting by five o'clock
They wrapped filming on the movie yesterday

definitions: move with urgent haste or at high speed
do something too quickly without proper care or thought
examples: She rushed to catch the last train home
Emergency vehicles rushed to the accident scene
Don't rush your homework or you'll make mistakes
They rushed the product to market too soon

definitions: reduce speed or cause to move or happen more slowly than before
examples: Please slow down when driving through the neighborhood
The medication may slow your heart rate

definitions: strive to gain or win something by defeating or establishing superiority over others
examples: Athletes from many countries compete in the Olympics
Several companies compete for the government contract

definitions: have official power or authority over a country, people, or domain
give an authoritative or official decision about a legal matter
examples: The emperor ruled the vast empire for decades
She rules the department with fairness and wisdom
The judge will rule on the motion tomorrow
The referee ruled that the goal was valid

definitions: receive an advantage, profit, or gain from something
provide help, advantage, or profit to someone or something
examples: Students benefit from smaller class sizes
You'll benefit from regular exercise and healthy eating
This new policy will benefit working families
The charity event will benefit local hospitals

definitions: return to a normal state of health, mind, strength, or position after illness or difficulty
get back or regain possession or control of something lost or stolen
examples: She's recovering well from her surgery
The economy is slowly recovering from the recession
Police recovered the stolen paintings
He never recovered the money he had lent

definitions: draw into the mouth by creating a partial vacuum with the lips and tongue
be very bad, unpleasant, or disagreeable in informal usage
examples: The baby learned to suck milk from a bottle
Use a straw to suck the juice
This movie really sucks
It sucks that you can't come to the party

definitions: clean something with water and usually soap or detergent
examples: Remember to wash your hands before eating dinner
She needs to wash the car this weekend

definitions: cause liquid to flow from a container in a steady stream
rain heavily without stopping
examples: Pour the milk slowly into the mixing bowl
She poured coffee for all the guests
It's been pouring all day
We can't go out while it's pouring like this

definitions: buy or obtain an asset, object, or skill for oneself through effort or payment
examples: The museum acquired several rare paintings last year
She worked hard to acquire fluency in Spanish

definitions: make or become longer or wider by pulling or being pulled
straighten or extend one's body or limbs to full length
examples: Don't stretch the sweater or it will lose shape
The highway stretches for miles through the desert
Athletes should stretch before and after exercise
She stretched her arms above her head

definitions: examine something methodically and in detail to explain and interpret it
examples: Scientists analyze data to test their hypotheses
We need to analyze the market before launching

definitions: break up and move earth with a tool, machine, or hands
search for information by careful investigation or research
examples: The dog likes to dig holes in the garden
Workers dig the foundation for the new building
Reporters dig for facts about the scandal
I had to dig through old files to find it

definitions: behave so as to make it appear that something is the case when it is not
examples: Children love to pretend they're superheroes
She pretended not to notice his mistake

definitions: move someone or something to a position that is below or less high
reduce the amount, level, or strength of something
examples: Lower the flag to half-mast
She lowered herself carefully into the chair
The store lowered prices to attract customers
Please lower your voice in the library

definitions: form an idea of the amount, number, or value of something through careful appraisal
examples: Teachers evaluate students through tests and assignments
The committee will evaluate all proposals next week

definitions: say or write something as an answer or response to someone or something
examples: Please reply to the email by Friday
She didn't reply when I asked her opinion

definitions: fill a suitcase, bag, or container with clothes and other items needed for travel
come together in large numbers to fill or crowd into a space
examples: Don't forget to pack your toothbrush
She packed all her belongings into boxes
Fans packed the stadium for the championship game
People packed into the small room

definitions: pull or rip something apart or to pieces with force
produce tears from the eyes as an emotional response
examples: Be careful not to tear the paper
The dog will tear the toy to pieces
The sad movie made everyone tear up
She couldn't help but tear at the funeral

definitions: vary or extend between specified limits in amount, degree, or scope
move over a wide area in search of something
examples: Prices range from fifty to two hundred dollars
The discussion ranged over many different topics
Cattle range freely on the open prairie
Wild animals range across vast territories

definitions: make a sudden sharp explosive sound like that of a cork leaving a bottle
go somewhere quickly or for a short time
examples: The balloon will pop if you squeeze it
Champagne corks popped at midnight
I'll just pop to the store for milk
She popped into the office to check messages

definitions: make movement or flow difficult or impossible through an obstacle
prevent something from happening or progressing
examples: A fallen tree blocks the road
Don't block the emergency exit
The firewall blocks harmful websites
They tried to block the new legislation

definitions: place or fix equipment or machinery in position ready for use
examples: The technician will install your new internet router tomorrow
We need to install new software on all computers

definitions: receive or entertain guests at one's home or at an event
provide the space or facilities for an event or service
examples: They love to host dinner parties
Who will host the awards ceremony this year
The city will host the international conference
This server hosts multiple websites

definitions: move a spoon or other implement through liquid or soft food to mix it
arouse strong feelings or emotions in someone
examples: Stir the soup to prevent it from burning
Add sugar and stir until it dissolves
The speech stirred patriotic feelings in the crowd
The news stirred controversy across the nation

definitions: give special importance or prominence to something when speaking or writing
examples: The teacher emphasized the importance of daily practice
I want to emphasize that safety comes first

definitions: put a heavy or large quantity of something on or in a vehicle or container
transfer data or a program into a computer or electronic device
examples: Workers load trucks with packages for delivery
Don't load the washing machine too full
Wait for the webpage to load completely
The app takes forever to load on my phone

definitions: achieve or complete something successfully through effort, skill, or courage
examples: She accomplished all her goals before turning thirty
The team accomplished the project ahead of schedule

definitions: be composed or made up of particular elements or parts
examples: The committee consists of twelve members
A healthy diet consists of fruits, vegetables, and whole grains

definitions: conduct a formal meeting to evaluate a candidate or obtain information
examples: The company will interview five candidates tomorrow
Journalists interviewed witnesses after the accident

definitions: put or hide something underground by covering it with earth
cover or hide something completely so it cannot be seen or found
examples: They decided to bury their pet in the backyard
Pirates used to bury treasure on islands
Don't bury your feelings
The report was buried under piles of paperwork

definitions: train or instruct a team, group, or individual in sports or other activities
examples: She coaches the high school basketball team
He hired someone to coach him for job interviews

definitions: alter or move something slightly to achieve a desired result
adapt or become used to new conditions or circumstances
examples: Adjust the mirror so you can see clearly
You may need to adjust the temperature settings
It takes time to adjust to a new job
My eyes need to adjust to the darkness

definitions: help someone by doing part of their work or by providing resources
examples: Nurses assist doctors during surgical procedures
Can I assist you with your luggage

definitions: give authorization or consent for something to happen
officially allow someone to do something by giving formal permission
examples: Weather permitting, we'll have the picnic outside
The rules don't permit smoking in the building
The city permits street vendors in certain areas
You need a license to permit construction work

definitions: say something very loudly or call to someone who is far away
examples: Don't shout at me when you're angry
She had to shout over the loud music
